ground_truth: He takes out the ticket with a hint of bluster in his attitude, which is cut off by a cold rebuff from the European, leading him to gesture to the back of the train. Gandhi, nonplussed and feeling a little less sure of himself, reacts with a touch of irony. The porter, wanting to avoid trouble, reaches for Gandhi's suitcases, while Gandhi reaches into his waistcoat to produce a card for the conductor, leaving the porter amazed. He then turns and walks out of the compartment. Meanwhile, in a large Victorian parlor in a well-to-do home, Gandhi faces Khan, an impressive Indian, Singh, who is slighter and older but wiry, capable of physical and intellectual strength, and Khan's twenty-year-old son, Tyeb Mohammed. Something is said with dignity and strength that makes the statement bewildering, leaving Gandhi looking around helplessly. Mr. Baker, a wealthy white lawyer whose home it is, pokes the fire, slightly amused at Gandhi's naivety, while Gandhi holds a British legal document and lifts it pointedly, looking at Mr. Baker in disbelief. Mr. Baker smothers a smile as Gandhi looks at Khan incredulously, who smiles with eyes showing that it's no joke. Gandhi absorbs the inconceivable as his innocence fuses with anger at the injustice of it all. The chilling tone shakes Gandhi's firmness a little, while Khan studies him with wry interest. Gandhi glances at Tyeb Mohammed and Baker, then stiffens, plainly frightened by the challenge yet determined to take it. A wire basket is placed on supports over the fire. A small crowd of mostly Indian people, with a few curious Whites, gathers in front, where Gandhi whispers, trying to ignore the crowd as the English reporter waits skeptically. Nearby, five policemen, including a sergeant and four constables, try to be inconspicuous, with a horse-drawn paddy wagon beside them. Among the crowd are five or six women in saris, featuring Gandhi's wife, Ba, at the front, possessing delicate features and large expressive eyes but feeling ill at ease and uncertain, forcing herself to act against her wishes. Gandhi wets his lips nervously, glances with apprehension at the police, then takes notes from his pocket and moves to the front of the fire.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: He removes the pass with a suggestion of swagger in his demeanor, which is halted by a frigid snub from the European, leading him to motion to the end of the train. Gandhi, bewildered and feeling a bit less confident of himself, responds with a trace of sarcasm. The porter, wishing to avoid conflict, reaches for Gandhi's luggage, while Gandhi reaches into his vest to reveal a card for the conductor, leaving the porter astounded. He then turns and exits the compartment. Meanwhile, in a spacious Victorian salon in a prosperous residence, Gandhi faces Khan, a distinguished Indian, Singh, who is slighter and older but sinewy, capable of physical and intellectual power, and Khan's twenty-year-old son, Tyeb Mohammed. Something is spoken with decorum and force that renders the assertion puzzling, leaving Gandhi glancing around helplessly. Mr. Baker, a affluent white attorney whose home it is, stirs the fire, slightly entertained at Gandhi's innocence, while Gandhi holds a British legal paper and raises it meaningfully, gazing at Mr. Baker in disbelief. Mr. Baker conceals a grin as Gandhi looks at Khan incredulously, who smiles with eyes showing that it's no jest. Gandhi absorbs the inconceivable as his naivety fuses with indignation at the injustice of it all. The chilling tone shakes Gandhi's resolve a bit, while Khan observes him with dry interest. Gandhi glances at Tyeb Mohammed and Baker, then stiffens, obviously scared by the challenge yet resolved to accept it. A wire container is placed on stands over the fire. A small assembly of primarily Indian individuals, with a few inquisitive Whites, assembles in front, where Gandhi murmurs, striving to disregard the assembly as the English reporter waits doubtfully. Nearby, five officers, including a sergeant and four constables, strive to be unobtrusive, with a horse-drawn patrol wagon beside them. Among the assembly are five or six women in saris, featuring Gandhi's spouse, Ba, at the front, possessing delicate features and large expressive eyes but feeling uncomfortable and uncertain, compelling herself to act against her desires. Gandhi moistens his lips anxiously, glances with worry at the officers, then takes notes from his pocket and moves to the front of the fire.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The ticket is taken out by him with a hint of bluster in his attitude, which cuts off a cold rebuff from the European, leading him to be gestured to the back of the train. Gandhi, nonplussed and feeling a little less sure of himself, is reacted to with a touch of irony by him. The suitcases are reached for by the porter, wanting to avoid trouble, while a card for the conductor is produced by Gandhi as he reaches into his waistcoat, leaving the porter amazed. The compartment is then turned from and walked out of by him. Meanwhile, in a large Victorian parlor in a well-to-do home, Khan is faced by Gandhi, an impressive Indian, Singh, who is slighter and older but wiry, capable of physical and intellectual strength, and Khan's twenty-year-old son, Tyeb Mohammed. Dignity and strength say something that makes the statement bewildering, leaving Gandhi looking around helplessly. The fire is poked by Mr. Baker, a wealthy white lawyer whose home it is, slightly amused at Gandhi's naivety, while a British legal document is held by Gandhi and lifted pointedly, looking at Mr. Baker in disbelief. A smile is smothered by Mr. Baker as Khan is looked at incredulously by Gandhi, who smiles with eyes showing that it's no joke. The inconceivable is absorbed by Gandhi as his innocence fuses with anger at the injustice of it all. A chilling tone shakes a little of Gandhi's firmness, while he is studied by Khan with wry interest. Tyeb Mohammed and Baker are glanced at by Gandhi, then he stiffens, plainly frightened by the challenge yet determined to take it. Supports over the fire are placed with a wire basket. A small crowd of mostly Indian people, with a few curious Whites, gathers in front, where a whisper is made by Gandhi, trying to ignore the crowd as the English reporter waits skeptically. Nearby, five policemen, including a sergeant and four constables, do their best to be inconspicuous, with a horse-drawn paddy wagon beside them. The crowd includes five or six women in saris, with Gandhi's wife, Ba, at the front, possessing delicate features and large expressive eyes but feeling ill at ease and uncertain, forcing herself to act against her wishes. Nervously, Gandhi wets his lips, glances apprehensively at the police, then notes are taken from his pocket by him and he moves to the front of the fire.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: With a hint of bluster, he takes out the ticket but is coldly rebuffed by the European, prompting him to gesture to the back of the train. Gandhi, less sure of himself, reacts ironically. The porter, avoiding trouble, reaches for Gandhi's suitcases, while Gandhi presents a card to the conductor, astounding the porter, and then exits the compartment. In a large Victorian parlor, Gandhi faces Khan, an impressive Indian; Singh, older but robust; and Khan's son, Tyeb Mohammed. A dignified statement leaves Gandhi bewildered. Mr. Baker, a wealthy lawyer, pokes the fire, amused at Gandhi's naivety. Gandhi holds a British legal document, incredulous, as Mr. Baker hides a smile. Gandhi's innocence turns to anger at the injustice, shaken by the chilling tone, while Khan observes him wryly. Gandhi, frightened yet determined, glances at Tyeb Mohammed and Baker. A wire basket is placed over the fire. A mostly Indian crowd, with a few curious Whites, gathers as Gandhi whispers, ignoring the crowd as a skeptical English reporter waits. Five policemen stand nearby, with a paddy wagon. Among the observers are women in saris, including Gandhi's wife, Ba, front and uneasy. Gandhi wets his lips, eyes the police nervously, takes notes from his pocket, and approaches the fire.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: With a hint of bluster, he takes out the ticket, but a cold rebuff from the European makes him gesture to the back of the train. Nonplussed, Gandhi responds with irony. The porter, avoiding trouble, reaches for Gandhi's suitcases, amazed when Gandhi produces a card for the conductor and exits the compartment. In a Victorian parlor, Gandhi faces Khan, Singh, and Khan's son, Tyeb Mohammed. A dignified statement leaves Gandhi bewildered. Wealthy lawyer Mr. Baker, amused by Gandhi's naivety, pokes the fire as Gandhi incredulously raises a British legal document. Mr. Baker smothers a smile, while Khan seriously observes Gandhi's shock and anger at the injustice. Stiffening with fright yet determined, Gandhi glances at Tyeb and Baker. Outside, a crowd, mostly Indian with a few curious Whites, gathers. Gandhi whispers, ignoring the skeptical English reporter. Five policemen, including a sergeant, remain inconspicuous near a paddy wagon. Among women in saris, Ba, Gandhi's wife, appears uneasy but determined. Nervous, Gandhi glances at the police, then moves to the front with notes, ready to speak.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
With a hint of bluster evident in his demeanor, he confidently takes out the ticket. However, this confident attitude is abruptly interrupted by a cold and dismissive rebuff from the European. In response, he gestures towards the back of the train. Gandhi, feeling nonplussed and experiencing a bit of self-doubt, reacts with a subtle touch of irony. The porter, eager to avoid any trouble, begins to reach for Gandhi's suitcases. At the same time, Gandhi reaches into his waistcoat to retrieve a card meant for the conductor, which leaves the porter utterly amazed. Gandhi then turns around and walks out of the compartment.

Meanwhile, in the setting of a large Victorian parlor within a well-to-do household, Gandhi finds himself in the company of Khan, who is an impressive figure from India. Also present is Singh, a man who appears slighter in stature and is older, yet exhibits wiry strength and is capable of both physical and intellectual prowess. Khan's son, Tyeb Mohammed, a young man of twenty years, is also there. A statement is made with such dignity and forcefulness that it leaves the statement bewildering, causing Gandhi to look around the room helplessly. Mr. Baker, a wealthy white lawyer who happens to be the owner of the home, is busy poking the fire. He seems slightly amused at Gandhi's apparent naivety, while Gandhi holds up a British legal document, lifting it pointedly as he looks at Mr. Baker in disbelief. Mr. Baker struggles to suppress a smile as Gandhi turns his incredulous gaze towards Khan, who smiles back with eyes that indicate he is quite serious, offering no joke. Gandhi tries to absorb the inconceivable reality, feeling his innocence gradually giving way to a rising anger at the injustice of it all. The chilling tone of the situation slightly shakes Gandhi's firm resolve, while Khan studies him with a look of wry interest. Gandhi glances over at Tyeb Mohammed and then at Baker, steeling himself despite the apparent fear of the challenge ahead, yet determined to face it head-on.

Nearby, a wire basket is carefully placed on supports over the fire. A small crowd has gathered in front, consisting mostly of Indian people with a few curious whites mingling among them. In this crowd, Gandhi whispers as he attempts to ignore their presence, while an English reporter waits with a skeptical expression. Close by, five policemen, including a sergeant and four constables, try to remain inconspicuous, standing beside a horse-drawn paddy wagon. Among the gathered crowd are five or six women dressed in saris, prominently featuring Gandhi's wife, Ba, at the forefront. She possesses delicate features and large, expressive eyes but feels uneasy and uncertain, forcing herself to act against her own wishes. Gandhi nervously wets his lips, casting an apprehensive glance in the direction of the police. He then takes notes from his pocket and approaches the front of the fire.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
With a noticeable hint of bluster evident in his demeanor, the man confidently and assuredly takes out the ticket from his pocket. However, this air of confidence is suddenly and quite unexpectedly interrupted by a cool, cold, and dismissive rebuff from the European. In response to this unexpected attitude, he gestures with a pointed finger towards the back of the train. Gandhi, feeling somewhat nonplussed and experiencing a creeping sense of self-doubt, reacts with a subtle touch of irony in his expression. The porter, eager to avoid any trouble or inconvenience, begins to reach out for Gandhi's suitcases. Simultaneously, Gandhi reaches into his waistcoat to retrieve a card intended for the conductor, which leaves the porter utterly amazed and taken aback. Gandhi then turns around decisively and walks out of the compartment.

Meanwhile, in the setting of an expansive and grand Victorian parlor within a well-to-do household, Gandhi finds himself in the company of Khan, who is an impressive and commanding figure from India. Also present in the room is Singh, a man who appears slighter in stature and is older, yet he exhibits wiry strength and is capable of both physical and intellectual prowess. Khan's son, Tyeb Mohammed, a young man of twenty years, is also present. A statement is made with such dignity and forcefulness that it leaves the statement bewildering, causing Gandhi to look around the room helplessly and with uncertainty. Mr. Baker, a wealthy and influential white lawyer who happens to be the owner of the home, is busy tending to the fire with a poker. He seems slightly amused at Gandhi's apparent naivety, while Gandhi holds up a British legal document, lifting it pointedly as he looks at Mr. Baker in disbelief. Mr. Baker struggles to suppress a smile as Gandhi turns his incredulous gaze towards Khan, who smiles back with eyes that clearly indicate he is quite serious, with no hint of a joke. Gandhi tries to absorb the inconceivable reality of the situation, feeling his innocence gradually giving way to a rising anger at the injustice of it all. The chilling tone of the situation slightly shakes Gandhi’s firm resolve, while Khan studies him with a look of wry and knowing interest. Gandhi glances over at Tyeb Mohammed and then at Baker, steeling himself despite the apparent fear of the challenge ahead, yet determined to face it head-on and with courage.

Nearby, a wire basket is carefully placed on supports over the fire, casting a glow. A small crowd has gathered in front, consisting mostly of Indian people with a few curious whites mingling among them. In the midst of this crowd, Gandhi whispers as he attempts to ignore their presence, while an English reporter waits with a skeptical and questioning expression. Close by, five policemen, including a sergeant and four constables, try to remain inconspicuous and unnoticed, standing beside a horse-drawn paddy wagon. Among the gathered crowd are five or six women dressed in colorful saris, prominently featuring Gandhi's wife, Ba, at the forefront. She possesses delicate features and large, expressive eyes but feels uneasy and uncertain, forcing herself to act against her own wishes. Gandhi nervously wets his lips, casting an apprehensive glance in the direction of the police. He then takes notes from his pocket and approaches the front of the fire with determination.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He reaches into his pocket to retrieve the ticket, displaying a hint of bluster in his manner, but this confident demeanor is abruptly interrupted by a cold and dismissive reaction from the European, who disregards him with a gesture towards the back of the train. This unexpected rebuff leaves Gandhi momentarily nonplussed and slightly less sure of himself, prompting a reaction tinged with irony. Seeing the potential for conflict, the porter, eager to avoid any trouble, reaches out to handle Gandhi's suitcases. In response, Gandhi slips his hand into his waistcoat, producing a card intended for the conductor, which leaves the porter amazed at his unexpected preparedness. Gandhi then turns away from the scene and exits the compartment, leaving behind the tension of the confrontation. Meanwhile, in a spacious Victorian parlor that exudes the wealth of its well-to-do owner, Gandhi stands facing Khan, an impressive Indian figure, alongside Singh, who is slighter in build, older yet wiry, exuding a combination of physical and intellectual vigor, and Khan's young son, Tyeb Mohammed, who is twenty years old. A statement is uttered with an air of dignity and strength that is so profound it bewilders Gandhi and leaves him casting his gaze around helplessly, struggling to grasp the gravity of the situation. Mr. Baker, the affluent white lawyer and owner of the house, tends to the fire with an air of mild amusement at Gandhi's apparent naivety. In response, Gandhi holds up a British legal document, lifting it with a sense of pointed disbelief as he directs his incredulous gaze towards Mr. Baker. The lawyer suppresses a smile, while Gandhi turns his incredulous gaze to Khan, whose smile and eyes convey that the situation is all too real. Gandhi processes the inconceivable reality, feeling his innocence meld with a growing anger at the blatant injustice. This chilling realization shakes his earlier confidence, while Khan observes him with a mix of wry interest. Gandhi, feeling the weight of the moment, glances toward Tyeb Mohammed and Mr. Baker, then resolves himself, stiffening with a mix of fear and determination as he faces the formidable challenge. A wire basket is positioned on supports over the fire, serving as a focal point. A diverse crowd, mainly composed of Indian individuals with a few curious White onlookers, gathers in eager anticipation. Among them, Gandhi, speaking in a low whisper in an effort to tune out the crowd, remains aware of the skeptical gaze of an English reporter. Nearby, five policemen, including a sergeant and four constables, attempt to blend in and maintain a low profile, despite the presence of a horse-drawn paddy wagon parked beside them. In the crowd are five or six women adorned in saris, with Gandhi's wife, Ba, leading the group. Her delicate features and large expressive eyes reveal her unease and uncertainty, although she strives to act against her reluctance. Gandhi, feeling the pressure of the situation, nervously wets his lips, casting a wary glance at the nearby police officers, before retrieving his notes from his pocket and advancing to the forefront of the fire.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi takes out his ticket with a confident attitude but is quickly rebuffed by the European, prompting him to gesture toward the back of the train. Unfazed, Gandhi responds with irony as the porter reaches for his suitcases, and he presents a card to the conductor, leaving the porter amazed before exiting the compartment. Meanwhile, in a large Victorian parlor, Gandhi faces Khan and Singh, both impressive figures, along with Khan's son, Tyeb Mohammed. A dignified statement leaves Gandhi bewildered as he looks helplessly around. Mr. Baker, the homeowner and a wealthy lawyer, amusedly tends the fire while Gandhi, holding a British legal document, looks at Baker in disbelief. Smiling wryly, Khan confirms the situation as Gandhi processes the injustice, his innocence giving way to anger. Though shaken, Gandhi glances at Tyeb Mohammed and Baker, frightened by the challenge but determined. Outside, a crowd of mostly Indian people, with a few curious Whites, gathers as Gandhi whispers and the English reporter observes skeptically. Nearby, policemen try to remain inconspicuous beside a horse-drawn paddy wagon. Among the crowd are several women in saris, including Gandhi's wife, Ba, with delicate features and expressive eyes, feeling uneasy but forcing herself to act. Gandhi, nervous, glances at the police, retrieves his notes, and approaches the fire.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description:
He takes out the train ticket for the first-class compartment with a hint of bluster in his attitude, which is cut off by a cold rebuff from the European railway official who is enforcing the racial segregation policies common in South Africa at the time, leading him to gesture to the back of the train. Gandhi, nonplussed and feeling a little less sure of himself, reacts with a touch of irony. The porter, wanting to avoid trouble and aware of the racial tensions prevalent in the area, reaches for Gandhi's suitcases, while Gandhi reaches into his waistcoat to produce a card for the conductor, a document asserting his legal right to be in first class, leaving the porter amazed. He then turns and walks out of the compartment. 

Meanwhile, in a large Victorian parlor in a well-to-do home in Johannesburg, Gandhi faces Khan, an impressive Indian community leader known for his advocacy, Singh, who is slighter and older but wiry, capable of physical and intellectual strength, and Khan's twenty-year-old son, Tyeb Mohammed. Something is said with dignity and strength that makes the statement bewildering, leaving Gandhi looking around helplessly. Mr. Baker, a wealthy white lawyer whose home it is and who is familiar with the racial tensions in the Transvaal, pokes the fire, slightly amused at Gandhi's naivety regarding local customs, while Gandhi holds a British legal document, perhaps a law journal or court ruling, and lifts it pointedly, looking at Mr. Baker in disbelief. Mr. Baker smothers a smile as Gandhi looks at Khan incredulously, who smiles with eyes showing that it's no joke. Gandhi absorbs the inconceivable as his innocence fuses with anger at the injustice of it all. The chilling tone shakes Gandhi's firmness a little, while Khan studies him with wry interest. Gandhi glances at Tyeb Mohammed and Baker, then stiffens, plainly frightened by the challenge yet determined to take it. 

A wire basket is placed on supports over the fire, a makeshift kitchen setup for hospitality. A small crowd of mostly Indian people, who are supporting Gandhi's cause of fighting racial injustice in South Africa, with a few curious Whites, gathers in front, where Gandhi whispers, attempting to rally morale while trying to ignore the crowd as the English reporter, there to cover the burgeoning civil rights movement, waits skeptically. Nearby, five policemen, including a sergeant and four constables, try to be inconspicuous, with a horse-drawn paddy wagon used for arrests of protesters beside them. Among the crowd are five or six women in saris, featuring Gandhi's wife, Ba, at the front, possessing delicate features and large expressive eyes but feeling ill at ease and uncertain, forcing herself to act against her wishes in support of her husband's mission. Gandhi wets his lips nervously, glances with apprehension at the police, aware of the risk of arrest, then takes notes from his pocket and moves to the front of the fire, preparing to address the crowd.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The cat pulls out the umbrella with a flash of arrogance in its demeanor, which is interrupted by a warm greeting from the astronaut, prompting it to point toward the roof of the castle. Napoleon, flummoxed and feeling slightly less confident, responds with a dash of sarcasm. The baker, eager to avoid chaos, grabs for Napoleon's paintings, while Napoleon dives into his backpack to reveal a feather for the magician, leaving the baker astounded. The cat then spins and skips off the balcony. Meanwhile, in a grand medieval library in a modest village, Napoleon encounters Einstein, a distinguished musician, Tesla, who is taller and younger but agile, capable of both artistic and mechanical prowess, and Einstein's teenage apprentice, Isaac Newton. A remark is made with grace and power that renders the declaration perplexing, leaving Napoleon peering around aimlessly. Mr. Sanders, an affluent blacksmith whose dwelling this is, stokes the cauldron, mildly entertained by Napoleon's ignorance, while Napoleon clutches a mysterious map and waves it emphatically, gazing at Mr. Sanders in astonishment. Mr. Sanders hides a chuckle as Napoleon looks at Einstein skeptically, who grins with eyes revealing it's no jest. Napoleon absorbs the unfathomable as his naivety merges with frustration at the absurdity of it all. The soothing melody rattles Napoleon's resolve slightly, while Einstein observes him with sly interest. Napoleon glances at Isaac Newton and Sanders, then braces himself, clearly intimidated by the predicament yet resolute to confront it. An aluminum ladder is placed on stands over the cauldron. A modest assembly of mostly medieval folks, with a few intrigued fairies, gathers below, where Napoleon murmurs, trying to dismiss the gathering as the French artist waits doubtfully. Nearby, five jesters, including a captain and four jugglers, strive to blend in, with a steam-powered carriage beside them. Among the assembly are five or six elves in cloaks, including Napoleon's sister, Ana, at the forefront, displaying subtle features and wide curious eyes but feeling out of place and hesitant, compelling herself to proceed contrary to her instincts. Napoleon moistens his mouth uneasily, peers with unease at the jesters, then retrieves manuscripts from his satchel and strides to the edge of the cauldron.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Gandhi presents his train ticket with confidence, but a European rebuffs him, leading the porter to reach for his suitcases and Gandhi to produce a card, surprising the porter. In a Victorian parlor, Gandhi faces Khan, Singh, and Khan's son, Tyeb Mohammed. A dignified statement leaves Gandhi bewildered, while Mr. Baker, a wealthy lawyer, observes amusedly. Holding a British legal document, Gandhi looks at Baker and Khan incredulously, absorbing the injustice with growing anger. Despite the challenge and his fear, Gandhi remains determined. At a gathering by a fire, a small crowd of Indians, including Gandhi's wife, Ba, and a few curious Whites watch as Gandhi nervously prepares to speak, ignoring the skeptical English reporter. Nearby, policemen try to blend in, while Ba feels uneasy and forced to act against her wishes.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: Gandhi wets his lips nervously glances with apprehension at the police then takes notes from his pocket and moves to the front of the fire Among the crowd are five or six women in saris featuring Gandhi's wife Ba at the front possessing delicate features and large expressive eyes but feeling ill at ease and uncertain forcing herself to act against her wishes Nearby five policemen including a sergeant and four constables try to be inconspicuous with a horsedrawn paddy wagon beside them A small crowd of mostly Indian people with a few curious Whites gathers in front where Gandhi whispers trying to ignore the crowd as the English reporter waits skeptically A wire basket is placed on supports over the fire Gandhi glances at Tyeb Mohammed and Baker then stiffens plainly frightened by the challenge yet determined to take it The chilling tone shakes Gandhi's firmness a little while Khan studies him with wry interest Gandhi absorbs the inconceivable as his innocence fuses with anger at the injustice of it all Mr Baker smothers a smile as Gandhi looks at Khan incredulously who smiles with eyes showing that it is no joke Mr Baker a wealthy white lawyer whose home it is pokes the fire slightly amused at Gandhi's naivety while Gandhi holds a British legal document and lifts it pointedly looking at Mr Baker in disbelief Something is said with dignity and strength that makes the statement bewildering leaving Gandhi looking around helplessly Meanwhile in a large Victorian parlor in a welltodo home Gandhi faces Khan an impressive Indian Singh who is slighter and older but wiry capable of physical and intellectual strength and Khan's twentyyearold son Tyeb Mohammed He then turns and walks out of the compartment The porter wanting to avoid trouble reaches for Gandhi's suitcases while Gandhi reaches into his waistcoat to produce a card for the conductor leaving the porter amazed Gandhi nonplussed and feeling a little less sure of himself reacts with a touch of irony He takes out the ticket with a hint of bluster in his attitude which is cut off by a cold rebuff from the European leading him to gesture to the back of the train
